item.title: ECB’s Guindos Says Euro Gain Past $1.20 Would Be Complicated
item.description: European Central Bank Vice President Luis de Guindos said an advance in the euro beyond $1.20 could prove tricky for policymakers but current levels aren’t cause for concern.
item.dc:creator: Francine Lacqua, Jana Randow

media:content.media:description: Luis de Guindos at the ECB Forum on Central Banking in Sintra, on July 1. Photographer: Goncalo Fonseca/Bloomberg

item.title: IMF Backs Swiss Bank Reform Push Amid UBS Capital Standoff
item.description: Switzerland’s planned financial regulation reforms are “bold” and should make the country more resistant to crises, the International Monetary Fund said, giving tacit support to the government in its standoff over capital with UBS Group AG.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: A UBS Group AG bank branch in Zurich.

item.title: Indonesia Raises Budget Deficit Outlook Near 3% Legal Limit
item.description: Indonesia expects to post a much bigger budget deficit this year due to weak revenue collections and the acceleration of President Prabowo Subianto’s priority programs.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: Sri Mulyani Indrawat

item.title: New BOJ Board Member Signals Support for Ueda’s Careful Stance
item.description: New Bank of Japan Board Member Kazuyuki Masu indicated that he backs Governor Kazuo Ueda’s gradual and cautious approach for raising interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Kazuyuki Masu Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Euro-Zone Inflation Ticks Higher to Match ECB’s 2% Target
item.description: Euro-area inflation settled at the European Central Bank’s target in June, strengthening arguments to press pause on a year-long campaign of interest-rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

item.title: Carney Gives Trump a Small Trade Victory in Hunt for Larger Deal
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney handed US President Donald Trump a win in the hope of making bigger gains in trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion, Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney and Donald Trump during the Group of Seven Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada on June 16.

item.title: South African Factory Mood Brightens as Local Demand Improves
item.description: Sentiment among South African manufacturers improved in June as a recovery in local demand boosted new sales.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: A worker on the automobile production line at an automobile manufacturing plant in Durban.

item.title: BOE Governor Bailey Hints at Slowing Pace of QT Bond Sales
item.description: The Bank of England is looking at the possibility of offloading fewer government bonds over the coming year than the current £100 billion ($138 billion) annual run-off rate amid questions about market demand for longer-dated government debt, Governor Andrew Bailey said.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey

item.title: Britain’s Manufacturing Decline Eases to Pre-Trump Tariff Levels
item.description: UK factory activity declined at its slowest pace since January and optimism improved, in signs that the sector is stabilizing after the double whammy of domestic tax increases and global tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: A worker monitors a machine making stainless steel rebar at a steel bar finishing unit in Sheffield.

item.title: EU to Accept Trump Universal Tariff But Seeks Key Exemptions
item.description: The European Union is willing to accept a trade arrangement with the US that includes a 10% universal tariff on many of the bloc’s exports, but wants the US to commit to lower rates than that on key sectors such as pharmaceuticals, alcohol, semiconductors and commercial aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

item.title: ECB Says Consumers’ Inflation Expectations Declined In May
item.description: Inflation expectations of euro-area consumers eased in May, the European Central Bank said.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Langley

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Germany. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Kazaks Says Any Further Rate Adjustments Won’t Be Big
item.description: The European Central Bank will make minor changes to borrowing costs at best as long as the economy develops in line with the most recent projections, according to Governing Council member Martins Kazaks.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Martins Kazaks

item.title: Swiss Manufacturing Jumps on Hope for Tariff Deal With US
item.description: Swiss manufacturing rose much more than anticipated in June, reflecting hope that a solution to the ongoing tariff spat with the US can be found as the July 9 deadline looms.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: An employee at the Stadler Rail AG plant in Bussnang, Switzerland.

item.title: Starmer’s Welfare Overhaul Hangs in Balance Ahead of Vote
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is girding for what could be the most consequential vote of his premiership, with dozens of Labour rebels expecting to vote against the government’s welfare overhaul despite huge concessions to push it through parliament.
item.dc:creator: Ailbhe Rea, Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer Source: UK Parliament

item.title: Escriva Says Symmetric 2% Goal Should Remain ECB’s Primary Guide
item.description: The European Central Bank is right to focus on a symmetric 2% inflation target, according to Governing Council member Jose Luis Escriva.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Jose Luis Escriva Photographer: Michael Robinson Chavez/Bloomberg

item.title: UK House Prices Post Sharpest Drop Since 2023 Amid Tax Rise
item.description: UK house prices fell the most in more than two years in June, in a sign buyers are under pressure after an increase in transaction taxes in April, according to one of Britain’s top mortgage lenders.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Residential homes in view of the London skyline.

item.title: ECB’s Nagel Sees Inflation in ‘Calmer Waters’ But Caution Needed
item.description: The European Central Bank has brought inflation under control but mustn’t become complacent due to the highly volatile geopolitical backdrop, according to Governing Council member Joachim Nagel.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber, Francine Lacqua

media:content.media:description: Joachim Nagel Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Macau Gaming Revenue Soars Past Estimate on Concert Fervor
item.description: Macau’s monthly gaming revenue rose 19% in June, exceeding analyst expectations as visitors poured in to the world’s biggest gambling hub for Cantonese pop concerts and other entertainment offerings.
item.dc:creator: Shirley Zhao, Lulu Shen

media:content.media:description: Casino resorts along the Cotai strip in Macau. Photographer: Eduardo Leal/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Simkus Warns of Fragile Inflation Path Due to Euro, Energy
item.description: The European Central Bank has fulfilled its inflation goal but volatility in foreign-exchange and commodities markets means the outlook for prices is murky, according to Governing Council member Gediminas Simkus.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Gediminas Simkus Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: Singapore Disease Testing Helps Fill the Gap Left by US Funding Cuts
item.description: Wastewater could offer clues to the next pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Karoline Kan

item.title: ECB Gets Another ‘Moderate Hawk’ as Dutch Central-Bank Veteran Exits
item.description: Olaf Sleijpen, the European Central Bank’s newest interest-rate setter, is about to continue where his Dutch predecessor left off.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: Olaf Sleijpen Source: De Nederlandsche Bank

item.title: China’s Private Factory Gauge Rebounds After US Trade Truce
item.description: China’s manufacturing activity rebounded in June, according to a private survey, suggesting relief after a trade-war truce with the US.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Yujing Liu

item.title: South Korean Exports Rebound in June on Record Chip Sales
item.description: South Korea’s exports rebounded on the back of record sales of semiconductors, providing a brief boost to the trade-dependent economy as companies accelerated shipments before broad duties on goods shipped to the US are set to rise.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: General Motors vehicles bound for export parked at the Port of Incheon. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Asia Manufacturing Slumps Anew Even as Some Data Show Resilience
item.description: The slowdown in Asia’s manufacturing activity deepened further in June, a warning sign for the region’s growth prospects as tariffs on shipments to the US are poised to increase next week.
item.dc:creator: Claire Jiao

item.title: Japan’s Business Confidence Beats Expectations Despite Tariffs
item.description: Confidence among Japan’s large manufacturers edged up in June, reflecting resilience in the face of the escalating US tariff campaign and backing the case for another Bank of Japan interest rate hike this year.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Toru Fujioka

item.title: Singapore Home Prices Rise for Third Quarter on Domestic Demand
item.description: Singapore private home prices rose for a third straight quarter, buoyed by local demand.
item.dc:creator: Dexter Low

item.title: Dalio Calls for Bipartisan Solution to Address US ‘Debt Bomb’
item.description: There is no way that the US “deficit/debt bomb” problem can be sustainably dealt with unless there is a bipartisan mix of tax revenue increases and spending decreases, Bridgewater Associates founder Ray Dalio wrote in a post on X.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Choy

media:content.media:description: Ray Dalio Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: New Zealand Firms Remain Upbeat Despite Weak Trading Conditions
item.description: New Zealand businesses were more upbeat about the future in the second quarter even as their own trading remained sluggish, according to the New Zealand Institute of Economic Research.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

item.title: UK Shop Prices Rise as Higher Taxes, Food Costs Hit Supermarkets
item.description: UK shop prices rose for the first time in almost a year, with supermarkets in particular hurt by higher taxes and wholesale costs.
item.dc:creator: Elliot Burrin

item.title: US Plans to Boost Soy Exports to Italy and Form New Task Force
item.description: Italy will increase its imports of US soybeans as part of a new effort to rebalance trade between the two countries, US Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins told reporters Monday after meeting with her Italian counterpart.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Peterson

media:content.media:description: Soybeans ready for planting at Double G Angus Farms in Tiffin, Iowa, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Soybean futures posted the biggest intraday gain in more than three weeks on Wednesday after the US and China confirmed trade talks, lifting market sentiment over demand for American crop supplies.
